project_metadata.paper_title: Early contact between late farming and pastoralist societies in southeastern Europe
project_metadata.research_context: Genome-wide analysis of 135 ancient individuals from southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning 5400-2400 BC, investigating early contact between late farming and pastoralist societies during the critical period between the demise of Copper Age settlements and the expansion of steppe pastoralists.

evidence.description: Sample size and temporal range of analysed ancient individuals
evidence.verbatim_quote: we analysed genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from the contact zone between southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning this critical time period

evidence.description: Genetic continuity between Neolithic and Copper Age groups
evidence.verbatim_quote: While we observe genetic continuity between Neolithic and Copper Age groups from major sites in the same region

evidence.description: Mixed ancestry detected in northwestern Black Sea region from 4500 BC
evidence.verbatim_quote: from around 4500 bc on, groups from the northwestern Black Sea region carried varying amounts of mixed ancestries derived from Copper Age groups and those from the forest/steppe zones

evidence.description: Early contact occurred 1000 years before anticipated
evidence.verbatim_quote: indicating genetic and cultural contact over a period of around 1,000 years earlier than anticipated

evidence.description: Varna cemetery dating and significance
evidence.verbatim_quote: The discovery of the necropolis of Varna (4600–4300 bc) on the Black Sea coast led to a reassessment of social inequality in human prehistory, with large quantities of gold and other symbols of power and wealth suggesting unprecedented levels of social stratification

evidence.description: Tell settlement abandonment timing
evidence.verbatim_quote: the roughly simultaneous abandonment of the numerous tell settlements and cemeteries around 4250/4200 bc appears enigmatic

evidence.description: Sample composition breakdown
evidence.verbatim_quote: In total, we report genome-wide data for 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals from eight distinct sites (Fig. 1) ranging from around 5400 to 2400 bc: Neolithic (n = 1), CA (n = 95), Eneolithic (n = 18) and EBA (n = 21)

evidence.description: SNP panel coverage
evidence.verbatim_quote: All samples were enriched for a panel of 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms (1,240,000 SNP panel), ranging from 61,000 to 947,000 SNPs with an average SNP coverage between 0.01× and 3.4×

evidence.description: New radiocarbon dates obtained
evidence.verbatim_quote: We also report 113 new radiocarbon dates

evidence.description: PCA methodology for genetic ancestry assessment
evidence.verbatim_quote: To assess the genetic ancestry and variation of the newly typed individuals we first performed principal component analysis (PCA) constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations, onto which data from the ancient individuals were projected

evidence.description: Earliest individual PIE039 genetic profile
evidence.verbatim_quote: The earliest-dated individual in our dataset, PIE039 from Pietrele, falls in the expected range of other SEE Neolithic individuals in PCA space, with whom she also shares affinities according to outgroup f3 statistics

evidence.description: SEE CA individuals cluster tightly in PCA
evidence.verbatim_quote: In PCA space, the chronologically younger SEE CA individuals from the emblematic sites of Yunatsite (YUN), Varna (VAR), Pietrele (PIE) and the multiple burial from Tell Petko Karavelovo (PTK), form a tight cluster that also overlaps with published Neolithic individuals from Anatolia and SEE

evidence.description: Outgroup f3 statistics confirm local genetic homogeneity
evidence.verbatim_quote: Moreover, outgroup f3 statistics suggest local genetic homogeneity throughout the CA in this region

evidence.description: SEE CA groups shifted towards EHG/WHG cline
evidence.verbatim_quote: However, all SEE CA groups are slightly shifted towards the EHG/WHG cline in both PC1 and PC2 compared to most published Neolithic individuals

evidence.description: Distal qpAdm modelling confirms ancestry composition
evidence.verbatim_quote: Distal qpAdm modelling (Fig. 3a and Supplementary Table G) confirmed minimal amounts of EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry, in addition to predominantly Turkey_N-like ancestry

evidence.description: Proximal qpAdm models support genetic continuity
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using the respective, locally preceding, Neolithic groups for proximal qpAdm modelling, we could model all SEE CA groups as a single-source model (Fig. 3d and Supplementary Table H), suggesting genetic continuity at the local scale

evidence.description: Outlier PIE060 shows excess HG ancestry
evidence.verbatim_quote: The outlier individual PIE060 is shifted further towards the WHG/EHG cluster in PCA, suggesting an excess of this type of ancestry, which could be confirmed by f4 statistics of the form f4(SEE N, PIE060; HGs, Mbuti) ((|Z| ≥ 3); Supplementary Table F)

evidence.description: PIE060 ancestry modelling results
evidence.verbatim_quote: Ancestry modelling with qpAdm supports a two-way model (Fig. 3d) with SEE N (around 65%) and Iron Gates HG or KO1 (around 35%) as the best proxies

evidence.description: DATES admixture timing estimate for PIE060
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using DATES to determine the time of admixture between SEE N and Iron Gates HG as a local HG ancestry, we obtained an admixture estimate of 16.3 ± 13.4 generations (Z = 1.213), which corresponds to around 81–832 years before the mean 14C date of PIE060

evidence.description: Y-chromosomal diversity in Pietrele
evidence.verbatim_quote: With seven different main lineages among 29 males in Pietrele (I2a1, C1a, G2a, H2, T1a, J2a and R1b-V88), six among 15 males in Varna (I2a1, I2a2, G2a, T1a, E1b1 and R1b-V88) and four among six males at Yunatsite (C1a, G2a, H2, J2a), the Y-chromosomal diversity during the SEE CA was higher than in central/western Europe

evidence.description: Limited first-degree relationships detected
evidence.verbatim_quote: When testing for genetic relatedness in each of the SEE CA sites using READ, we detected only three first-degree and two second-degree relationships in total

evidence.description: IBD analysis shows limited between-site links
evidence.verbatim_quote: We found no evidence for between-site links up to the fourth to fifth degree and only two pairs of individuals (PIE003-VAR010 and YUN005-VAR030) shared at least two blocks greater than 20 cM indicative of a fifth to seventh degree relationship

evidence.description: ROH analysis indicates low parental background relatedness
evidence.verbatim_quote: However, analysis of the runs of homozygosity (ROH) per individual using hapROH indicates low levels of parental background relatedness suggesting relatively large effective population sizes

evidence.description: Ukraine Eneolithic genetic cline in PCA
evidence.verbatim_quote: Eneolithic individuals from Ukraine (Ukraine Eneolithic), dated from around 4500–3500 bc, associated with the Cernavodă I and Usatove cultures, form a genetic cline in PCA space (Fig. 1b) between Neolithic/SEE CA individuals and published Eneolithic steppe individuals from the North Caucasus and Khvalynsk in western Russia

evidence.description: Chronological range of observed genetic cline
evidence.verbatim_quote: The observed genetic cline reflects developments over a wide chronological range of around 1,000 years

evidence.description: Potential freshwater reservoir effect on radiocarbon dates
evidence.verbatim_quote: Some of the newly reported 14C dates could be affected by a freshwater reservoir effect, common in Steppe Eneolithic sites and could therefore be several centuries younger than their reported dates

evidence.description: Kartal individuals show genetic heterogeneity
evidence.verbatim_quote: Individuals from Kartal (around 4150–3400 bc), associated with the Cernavodă I culture, are genetically highly heterogeneous, with five individuals (Kartal A) forming a cline between 'Steppe Eneolithic'/'Steppe Maykop' individuals and Early Neolithic groups, while three other individuals (Kartal B) fall closer to the latter

evidence.description: Majaky individuals more homogeneous
evidence.verbatim_quote: The five contemporaneous individuals from Majaky (MAJ), are genetically more homogeneous and fall together with the four individuals from the late Eneolithic Usatove type-site (USV/UBK; Supplementary Table A) in the middle of the 'Kartal cline'

evidence.description: No correlation between PC2 position and radiocarbon dates
evidence.verbatim_quote: We tested for a correlation between positions of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals in PC2 and their 14C dates and found none (Spearman's ρ = 0.113, P = 0.6656)

evidence.description: F4 symmetry statistics show excess HG affinity in Ukraine Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: First, compared to Turkey_N, Ukraine Eneolithic individuals show excess affinity to all HG groups, as indicated by significantly negative f4 statistics (|Z| ≥ 3)

evidence.description: Ukraine Eneolithic shows excess affinity to Turkey_N vs Steppe Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: Second, conditioning on Steppe Eneolithic (Extended Data Fig. 6b), we observe excess affinity of Ukraine Eneolithic to Turkey_N, a symmetrical relatedness to CHG and WHG, while Steppe Eneolithic groups carry more EHG/WSHG ancestry

evidence.description: Re-analysis of Cucuteni-Trypillia data
evidence.verbatim_quote: However, on re-analysis of these data we find that this signal can be explained solely by an increase in especially EHG-rich ancestry

evidence.description: F4 tests show Ukraine Eneolithic excess affinity to SEE CA
evidence.verbatim_quote: With respect to Steppe Eneolithic, all Ukraine Eneolithic individuals show excess affinity to all tested CA groups

evidence.description: Distal qpAdm four-way admixture model
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using distal qpAdm modelling we find support for a four-way admixture of Turkey_N, EHG, CHG and WHG for KTL001, KTL007, MAJ and USV

evidence.description: Proximal two-way models for Ukraine Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: Following up with proximal qpAdm models to explore potential contribution(s) of temporally and geographically closer groups (Fig. 3e and Supplementary Tables E and S), we find that all Ukraine Eneolithic individuals can be modelled as a two-way model of either VAR_CA or Ukraine Trypillia as farmer-related ancestry source and Steppe Eneolithic as a source of mixed EHG+CHG ancestry

evidence.description: KTL001 three-way mixture model
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using both associated ancestries and different HGs and SEE CA-related groups as sources in qpAdm modelling (Fig. 3e and Supplementary Table S), we find that KTL001 can indeed be modelled as a three-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic (around 32%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 46%) and Ukraine N foragers (around 22%), to the exclusion of a SEE CA source

evidence.description: MAJ and USV three-component model
evidence.verbatim_quote: By contrast, MAJ and USV can be modelled as VAR_CA or Ukraine Trypillia (around 50%), Steppe Eneolithic (around 35%) and Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 15%) as minor third component

evidence.description: Rotating model supports SEE CA contribution over Caucasus
evidence.verbatim_quote: Finally, to test whether we can distinguish between the farmer-related ancestry contributed by SEE CA- or Maykop-associated groups from the Caucasus, or by both, we rotated each source to the outgroups, alternatingly, keeping Steppe Eneolithic as a constant. Here, we find strong support for a genetic contribution from SEE CA rather than Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop for most KTL individuals

evidence.description: USV requires Maykop-associated ancestry
evidence.verbatim_quote: The same model is supported for MAJ (P = 0.05) but rejected for USV, which indicates that Maykop-associated ancestry is needed for the latter

evidence.description: IBD evidence for MAJ-USV relationship
evidence.verbatim_quote: The similarities in genetic ancestry presented for MAJ and USV are also observed in the results from the IBD analysis (Extended Data Fig. 4a and Supplementary Table J) in which we find a fourth to sixth degree relationship between MAJ023 and USV006

evidence.description: Elevated ROH in MAJ and USV
evidence.verbatim_quote: However, in comparison to the preceding CA and heterogenous KTL individuals, ROH indicate a slightly elevated parental background relatedness for MAJ and USV (Extended Data Fig. 5), suggesting smaller effective population sizes in Usatove-associated groups

evidence.description: Y-chromosomal lineages in Ukraine Eneolithic males
evidence.verbatim_quote: Y-chromosomal evidence from the six Ukraine Eneolithic males reflects lineages from each of the contributing sources (Extended Data Fig. 3b): G2a is probably a Neolithic legacy, while three males carrying I2a1 could be attributed to the local Ukrainian Neolithic or HG groups in general

evidence.description: Absence of R1b-Z2103 in Ukraine Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: Importantly, we do not observe R1b-Z2103 or immediate R1b-M269 precursor lineages, which originated in the steppe and are later linked with expansion of steppe-related ancestry

evidence.description: Contrasting EBA genetic clusters
evidence.verbatim_quote: The EBA individuals in this study are characterized by two contrasting clusters of genetic ancestry in PCA space (Fig. 1b) and different genetic affinities in outgroup f3 statistics (Fig. 2 and Supplementary Table C)

evidence.description: YUN EBA and PIE078 resemble SEE CA
evidence.verbatim_quote: Individuals from YUN and individual PIE078, who date to the first half of the third millennium BC, resemble the SEE CA groups, whereas BOY_EBA and MAJ_EBA individuals fall within the 'steppe ancestry' cluster, commonly associated with the Yamnaya cultural complex

evidence.description: Y-chromosome lineages distinguish EBA clusters
evidence.verbatim_quote: Intriguingly, the males from YUN_EBA/PIE078 carried Y-chromosome lineages I2a, suggestive of a HG legacy, while the males from BOY/MAJ_EBA carried R1b-Z2103 or derived lineages, a characteristic hallmark of Yamnaya-associated ancestry

evidence.description: Excess HG ancestry confirmed in YUN EBA and PIE078
evidence.verbatim_quote: On the basis of these observations we tested for additional attraction towards HG-related groups in YUN_EBA and PIE078 compared to their CA predecessors by using f4(CA, EBA; HGs, Mbuti) and confirmed the excess HG ancestry in EBA individuals from YUN and PIE with significant negative results (|Z| ≤ 3)

evidence.description: YUN041 outlier shows higher affinity to VAR_CA
evidence.verbatim_quote: Here, only the outlier individual YUN041 has a higher affinity to VAR_CA than to other EBA groups

evidence.description: Distal modelling confirms contrasting EBA ancestries
evidence.verbatim_quote: Distal qpAdm modelling with cornerstone populations confirms the contrasting ancestries of the two main EBA clusters. PIE078 and YUN_EBA can be modelled with Turkey_N, CHG and WHG (Fig. 3c and Supplementary Table X), whereas MAJ_EBA, BOY_EBA, BOY019 and YUN041 require EHG ancestry as an additional source

evidence.description: All EBA individuals show excess Turkey_N affinity vs Steppe Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: With the exception of Yamnaya Caucasus, all EBA individuals show an excess affinity to Turkey_N when compared to Steppe Eneolithic

evidence.description: Genetic similarity among Yamnaya-associated individuals
evidence.verbatim_quote: Here, with the exception of outlier individual Ukraine_Ozera_EBA_Yamnaya, all f4 statistics are non-significant (|Z| ≤ 3) (Supplementary Table W), which indicates that all Yamnaya-associated individuals including those from Ukraine and Bulgaria are genetically highly similar

evidence.description: BOY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara three-way mixture model
evidence.verbatim_quote: Applying the same rationale and sources to proximal qpAdm modelling to uncover subtle signals (Fig. 3f and Supplementary Table Y), we find that BOY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara can be modelled as a three-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic, Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop and Ukraine N

evidence.description: Ukraine EBA Yamnaya can be modelled with USV contribution
evidence.verbatim_quote: For Ukraine_EBA_Yamnaya, we find support for a three-way model (P = 0.07) with Steppe Eneolithic (around 75%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 14%) and Globular Amphora (around 11%) as a western source but also improved model fit (P = 0.5) for a two-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic (around 65%) and USV (around 35%)

evidence.description: Yamnaya Caucasus two-way model
evidence.verbatim_quote: By contrast, Yamnaya Caucasus individuals from the southern steppe can be modelled as a two-way model of around 76% Steppe Eneolithic and 26% Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop, confirming the findings of Lazaridis and colleagues

evidence.description: BOY019 modelling results
evidence.verbatim_quote: Individual BOY019 can be modelled successfully with around 63% USV and around 37% Steppe Eneolithic ancestry or around 40% Ukraine Trypillia and around 60% Steppe Eneolithic, suggesting interaction between these two neighbouring groups in the western contact zone or alternatively direct descent from admixed groups (for example, KTL001)

evidence.description: YUN041 modelling results
evidence.verbatim_quote: Finally, individual YUN041 can be modelled as around 50% local YUN_EBA ancestry and 50% of either BOY_EBA or another Yamnaya-associated source

evidence.description: HBV positive individuals detected
evidence.verbatim_quote: Despite the systematic screening of teeth, we found no evidence for pathogens among the CA individuals of the fifth and fourth millennium bc, apart from two individuals (YUN048 and VAR021), who were positive for the Hepatitis B virus (HBV), while individual VAR021 was also positive for Salmonella enterica

evidence.description: Ancient DNA laboratory location
evidence.verbatim_quote: Ancient DNA work was carried out in dedicated clean room facilities of the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology (MPI-EVA), Leipzig and Jena, Germany

evidence.description: Sample processing numbers
evidence.verbatim_quote: We processed 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth in total

evidence.description: DNA extraction method
evidence.verbatim_quote: DNA was extracted from all samples following a modified protocol refs. 63,64

evidence.description: Library preparation approach
evidence.verbatim_quote: DNA double-stranded libraries were built using a partial uracil-DNA-glycosylase (UDG-half) treatment

evidence.description: Endogenous DNA threshold
evidence.verbatim_quote: Libraries above the threshold of 0.1% endogenous DNA were enriched for around 1.2 million SNPs in a targeted in-solution capture (1,240,000 SNP capture)

evidence.description: Mean coverage achieved
evidence.verbatim_quote: Enriched libraries were sequenced on HiSeq4000 and NextSeq500 Illumina platforms using a single-read (SR 75) kit and sequencing 40 million reads for libraries between 0.1% and 2% or 20 million reads for libraries above 2%, resulting in a mean coverage of 0.7×

evidence.description: Mitochondrial capture coverage
evidence.verbatim_quote: An additional mitochondrial capture was performed for individuals for which enough reads could not be obtained as by-catch of the 1,240,000 capture, resulting in an average coverage of 64×

evidence.description: YMCA capture mean coverage
evidence.verbatim_quote: For selected male individuals we also performed an inhouse capture assay for the Y chromosome (YMCA) which targets around 10.445 kB on the non-combining region of the Y chromosome and which resulted in a mean coverage of 0.08×

evidence.description: DNA damage patterns characteristic of ancient DNA
evidence.verbatim_quote: All libraries, except PTK001, yielded damage patterns characteristic of ancient DNA, which includes short DNA fragment lengths (45–65 bp on average) and postmortem deamination at the end of the molecules (6–17% for partial UDG treatment, 30–38% for non-UDG treatment)

evidence.description: Contamination estimates
evidence.verbatim_quote: We merged Shotgun, 1,240,000 and mitochondrial capture data for each individual, mapped this against the revised Cambridge Reference Sequence for the complete human mitochondrial genome (NC 012920.1) and estimated contamination for both sexes on the mitochondrium using ContamMix (Supplementary Table A), ranging from 0.086% to −9.2%. The nuclear contamination for males was estimated using ANGSD and ranged from 0.2% to 2%

claims.description: Early contact between farming and pastoralist groups occurred ~1000 years earlier than anticipated
claims.verbatim_quote: indicating genetic and cultural contact over a period of around 1,000 years earlier than anticipated

claims.description: 135 ancient individuals spanning 5400-2400 BC were successfully analysed
claims.verbatim_quote: we analysed genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from the contact zone between southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning this critical time period

claims.description: Genetic continuity existed between Neolithic and Copper Age groups in SEE
claims.verbatim_quote: While we observe genetic continuity between Neolithic and Copper Age groups from major sites in the same region

claims.description: Groups in northwestern Black Sea region carried mixed ancestries from 4500 BC
claims.verbatim_quote: from around 4500 bc on, groups from the northwestern Black Sea region carried varying amounts of mixed ancestries derived from Copper Age groups and those from the forest/steppe zones

claims.description: Transfer of innovations during early contact was integral to formation of pastoralist groups
claims.verbatim_quote: We propose that the transfer of critical innovations between farmers and transitional foragers/herders from different ecogeographic zones during this early contact was integral to the formation, rise and expansion of pastoralist groups around 3300 bc

claims.description: Varna cemetery demonstrates unprecedented social stratification in prehistoric Europe
claims.verbatim_quote: The discovery of the necropolis of Varna (4600–4300 bc) on the Black Sea coast led to a reassessment of social inequality in human prehistory, with large quantities of gold and other symbols of power and wealth suggesting unprecedented levels of social stratification

claims.description: Tell settlements were simultaneously abandoned around 4250/4200 BC
claims.verbatim_quote: the roughly simultaneous abandonment of the numerous tell settlements and cemeteries around 4250/4200 bc appears enigmatic

claims.description: SNP capture achieved coverage of 61,000-947,000 SNPs per individual
claims.verbatim_quote: ranging from 61,000 to 947,000 SNPs with an average SNP coverage between 0.01× and 3.4×

claims.description: 113 new radiocarbon dates were generated for this study
claims.verbatim_quote: We also report 113 new radiocarbon dates

claims.description: PCA was constructed from 1,253 modern West Eurasians from 77 populations
claims.verbatim_quote: principal component analysis (PCA) constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations

claims.description: SEE CA individuals form a tight genetic cluster overlapping with Neolithic Anatolians
claims.verbatim_quote: the chronologically younger SEE CA individuals from the emblematic sites of Yunatsite (YUN), Varna (VAR), Pietrele (PIE) and the multiple burial from Tell Petko Karavelovo (PTK), form a tight cluster that also overlaps with published Neolithic individuals from Anatolia and SEE

claims.description: Local genetic homogeneity persisted throughout the Copper Age in SEE
claims.verbatim_quote: outgroup f3 statistics suggest local genetic homogeneity throughout the CA in this region

claims.description: SEE CA groups show slight shift towards EHG/WHG ancestry
claims.verbatim_quote: all SEE CA groups are slightly shifted towards the EHG/WHG cline in both PC1 and PC2 compared to most published Neolithic individuals

claims.description: SEE CA ancestry is predominantly Turkey_N with minimal HG admixture
claims.verbatim_quote: confirmed minimal amounts of EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry, in addition to predominantly Turkey_N-like ancestry

claims.description: All SEE CA groups can be modelled as single-source from local Neolithic
claims.verbatim_quote: we could model all SEE CA groups as a single-source model (Fig. 3d and Supplementary Table H), suggesting genetic continuity at the local scale

claims.description: PIE060 is an outlier with ~35% HG ancestry
claims.verbatim_quote: Ancestry modelling with qpAdm supports a two-way model (Fig. 3d) with SEE N (around 65%) and Iron Gates HG or KO1 (around 35%) as the best proxies

claims.description: PIE060 came from a community outside Pietrele with recent HG contact
claims.verbatim_quote: A flat decay curve (Extended Data Fig. 3a) supports the interpretation of a recent admixture date, which suggests that PIE060 came from a community outside Pietrele with recent contact with HGs

claims.description: Y-chromosomal diversity during SEE CA was higher than in central/western Europe
claims.verbatim_quote: the Y-chromosomal diversity during the SEE CA was higher than in central/western Europe

claims.description: Limited close genetic relatives were found within SEE CA sites
claims.verbatim_quote: we detected only three first-degree and two second-degree relationships in total

claims.description: No close genetic links exist between contemporaneous SEE CA sites
claims.verbatim_quote: We found no evidence for between-site links up to the fourth to fifth degree

claims.description: Low ROH indicates large effective population sizes in SEE CA
claims.verbatim_quote: ROH indicates low levels of parental background relatedness suggesting relatively large effective population sizes

claims.description: Ukraine Eneolithic individuals form a genetic cline between farmers and steppe groups
claims.verbatim_quote: Eneolithic individuals from Ukraine (Ukraine Eneolithic), dated from around 4500–3500 bc, associated with the Cernavodă I and Usatove cultures, form a genetic cline in PCA space (Fig. 1b) between Neolithic/SEE CA individuals and published Eneolithic steppe individuals

claims.description: The genetic cline reflects developments over ~1000 years
claims.verbatim_quote: The observed genetic cline reflects developments over a wide chronological range of around 1,000 years

claims.description: Radiocarbon dates may be affected by freshwater reservoir effect
claims.verbatim_quote: Some of the newly reported 14C dates could be affected by a freshwater reservoir effect, common in Steppe Eneolithic sites and could therefore be several centuries younger than their reported dates

claims.description: Kartal individuals are genetically highly heterogeneous
claims.verbatim_quote: Individuals from Kartal (around 4150–3400 bc), associated with the Cernavodă I culture, are genetically highly heterogeneous

claims.description: Majaky and Usatove individuals are genetically more homogeneous
claims.verbatim_quote: The five contemporaneous individuals from Majaky (MAJ), are genetically more homogeneous

claims.description: No correlation exists between PC2 position and radiocarbon dates in Ukraine Eneolithic
claims.verbatim_quote: We tested for a correlation between positions of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals in PC2 and their 14C dates and found none (Spearman's ρ = 0.113, P = 0.6656)

claims.description: Ukraine Eneolithic shows excess affinity to all HG groups compared to Turkey_N
claims.verbatim_quote: compared to Turkey_N, Ukraine Eneolithic individuals show excess affinity to all HG groups, as indicated by significantly negative f4 statistics (|Z| ≥ 3)

claims.description: Ukraine Eneolithic shows excess Turkey_N affinity compared to Steppe Eneolithic
claims.verbatim_quote: we observe excess affinity of Ukraine Eneolithic to Turkey_N, a symmetrical relatedness to CHG and WHG, while Steppe Eneolithic groups carry more EHG/WSHG ancestry

claims.description: Previously reported Yamnaya ancestry in Cucuteni-Trypillia is explained by EHG-rich ancestry alone
claims.verbatim_quote: on re-analysis of these data we find that this signal can be explained solely by an increase in especially EHG-rich ancestry

claims.description: All Ukraine Eneolithic individuals show excess affinity to SEE CA groups
claims.verbatim_quote: With respect to Steppe Eneolithic, all Ukraine Eneolithic individuals show excess affinity to all tested CA groups

claims.description: Distal modelling supports four-way admixture for several Ukraine Eneolithic groups
claims.verbatim_quote: Using distal qpAdm modelling we find support for a four-way admixture of Turkey_N, EHG, CHG and WHG for KTL001, KTL007, MAJ and USV

claims.description: All Ukraine Eneolithic can be modelled as two-way mixture of CA farmers and Steppe Eneolithic
claims.verbatim_quote: we find that all Ukraine Eneolithic individuals can be modelled as a two-way model of either VAR_CA or Ukraine Trypillia as farmer-related ancestry source and Steppe Eneolithic as a source of mixed EHG+CHG ancestry

claims.description: KTL001 shows three-way mixture excluding SEE CA ancestry
claims.verbatim_quote: KTL001 can indeed be modelled as a three-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic (around 32%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 46%) and Ukraine N foragers (around 22%), to the exclusion of a SEE CA source

claims.description: MAJ and USV show three-component ancestry including Caucasus contribution
claims.verbatim_quote: MAJ and USV can be modelled as VAR_CA or Ukraine Trypillia (around 50%), Steppe Eneolithic (around 35%) and Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 15%) as minor third component

claims.description: Strong support exists for SEE CA contribution over Caucasus for most Kartal individuals
claims.verbatim_quote: we find strong support for a genetic contribution from SEE CA rather than Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop for most KTL individuals

claims.description: Usatove requires Maykop-associated ancestry in addition to other sources
claims.verbatim_quote: The same model is supported for MAJ (P = 0.05) but rejected for USV, which indicates that Maykop-associated ancestry is needed for the latter

claims.description: IBD analysis confirms genetic similarity between MAJ and USV
claims.verbatim_quote: we find a fourth to sixth degree relationship between MAJ023 and USV006, which reflects the close geographical vicinity of the two sites

claims.description: MAJ and USV show smaller effective population sizes than preceding CA groups
claims.verbatim_quote: ROH indicate a slightly elevated parental background relatedness for MAJ and USV (Extended Data Fig. 5), suggesting smaller effective population sizes in Usatove-associated groups

claims.description: Y-chromosomal lineages in Ukraine Eneolithic reflect multiple contributing sources
claims.verbatim_quote: Y-chromosomal evidence from the six Ukraine Eneolithic males reflects lineages from each of the contributing sources

claims.description: R1b-Z2103 lineage absent in Ukraine Eneolithic males
claims.verbatim_quote: Importantly, we do not observe R1b-Z2103 or immediate R1b-M269 precursor lineages, which originated in the steppe and are later linked with expansion of steppe-related ancestry

claims.description: EBA individuals show two contrasting genetic ancestry clusters
claims.verbatim_quote: The EBA individuals in this study are characterized by two contrasting clusters of genetic ancestry in PCA space

claims.description: YUN EBA and PIE078 resemble SEE CA while BOY/MAJ EBA show steppe ancestry
claims.verbatim_quote: Individuals from YUN and individual PIE078, who date to the first half of the third millennium BC, resemble the SEE CA groups, whereas BOY_EBA and MAJ_EBA individuals fall within the 'steppe ancestry' cluster

claims.description: Y-chromosome lineages distinguish the two EBA clusters
claims.verbatim_quote: the males from YUN_EBA/PIE078 carried Y-chromosome lineages I2a, suggestive of a HG legacy, while the males from BOY/MAJ_EBA carried R1b-Z2103 or derived lineages, a characteristic hallmark of Yamnaya-associated ancestry

claims.description: YUN EBA and PIE078 show excess HG ancestry compared to CA predecessors
claims.verbatim_quote: confirmed the excess HG ancestry in EBA individuals from YUN and PIE with significant negative results (|Z| ≤ 3)

claims.description: YUN041 outlier shows higher affinity to local CA than other EBA groups
claims.verbatim_quote: only the outlier individual YUN041 has a higher affinity to VAR_CA than to other EBA groups

claims.description: Distal modelling confirms distinct ancestry sources for two EBA clusters
claims.verbatim_quote: PIE078 and YUN_EBA can be modelled with Turkey_N, CHG and WHG (Fig. 3c and Supplementary Table X), whereas MAJ_EBA, BOY_EBA, BOY019 and YUN041 require EHG ancestry as an additional source

claims.description: Most EBA individuals show excess Turkey_N affinity compared to Steppe Eneolithic
claims.verbatim_quote: With the exception of Yamnaya Caucasus, all EBA individuals show an excess affinity to Turkey_N when compared to Steppe Eneolithic

claims.description: Yamnaya-associated individuals from Ukraine and Bulgaria are genetically highly similar
claims.verbatim_quote: all f4 statistics are non-significant (|Z| ≤ 3) (Supplementary Table W), which indicates that all Yamnaya-associated individuals including those from Ukraine and Bulgaria are genetically highly similar

claims.description: BOY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara can be modelled as three-way mixture
claims.verbatim_quote: we find that BOY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara can be modelled as a three-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic, Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop and Ukraine N

claims.description: Ukraine Eneolithic groups may have directly contributed to steppe pastoralists
claims.verbatim_quote: improved model fit (P = 0.5) for a two-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic (around 65%) and USV (around 35%) (Supplementary Table Y), which suggests a possible direct contribution of Ukraine Eneolithic groups to steppe pastoralists in the third millennium bc

claims.description: Yamnaya Caucasus shows distinct ancestry composition from northern groups
claims.verbatim_quote: Yamnaya Caucasus individuals from the southern steppe can be modelled as a two-way model of around 76% Steppe Eneolithic and 26% Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop

claims.description: BOY019 demonstrates interaction between neighbouring groups in western contact zone
claims.verbatim_quote: BOY019 can be modelled successfully with around 63% USV and around 37% Steppe Eneolithic ancestry or around 40% Ukraine Trypillia and around 60% Steppe Eneolithic, suggesting interaction between these two neighbouring groups in the western contact zone

claims.description: YUN041 represents admixture between local EBA and Yamnaya-associated groups
claims.verbatim_quote: individual YUN041 can be modelled as around 50% local YUN_EBA ancestry and 50% of either BOY_EBA or another Yamnaya-associated source

claims.description: Pathogen screening found limited evidence of disease in CA individuals
claims.verbatim_quote: we found no evidence for pathogens among the CA individuals of the fifth and fourth millennium bc, apart from two individuals (YUN048 and VAR021), who were positive for the Hepatitis B virus (HBV)

claims.description: Ancient DNA work was conducted in dedicated clean room facilities
claims.verbatim_quote: Ancient DNA work was carried out in dedicated clean room facilities of the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology

claims.description: 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth were processed
claims.verbatim_quote: We processed 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth in total

claims.description: DNA extraction followed established modified protocols
claims.verbatim_quote: DNA was extracted from all samples following a modified protocol refs. 63,64

claims.description: UDG-half treatment was used for library preparation
claims.verbatim_quote: DNA double-stranded libraries were built using a partial uracil-DNA-glycosylase (UDG-half) treatment

claims.description: 0.1% endogenous DNA threshold was used for SNP capture
claims.verbatim_quote: Libraries above the threshold of 0.1% endogenous DNA were enriched for around 1.2 million SNPs

claims.description: Mean coverage of 0.7× was achieved
claims.verbatim_quote: resulting in a mean coverage of 0.7×

claims.description: Mitochondrial capture achieved 64× average coverage
claims.verbatim_quote: resulting in an average coverage of 64×

claims.description: Y-chromosome capture achieved 0.08× mean coverage
claims.verbatim_quote: resulted in a mean coverage of 0.08×

claims.description: DNA damage patterns confirm ancient origin of samples
claims.verbatim_quote: All libraries, except PTK001, yielded damage patterns characteristic of ancient DNA

claims.description: Contamination levels were low across samples
claims.verbatim_quote: estimated contamination for both sexes on the mitochondrium using ContamMix (Supplementary Table A), ranging from 0.086% to −9.2%. The nuclear contamination for males was estimated using ANGSD and ranged from 0.2% to 2%

implicit_arguments.description: Genetic data can accurately reconstruct population interactions from 5000+ years ago
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: we analysed genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals

implicit_arguments.description: Archaeological cultural boundaries correspond to genetic population boundaries
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: associated with the Cernavodă I and Usatove cultures, form a genetic cline

implicit_arguments.description: qpAdm modelling provides accurate ancestry proportions despite low coverage data
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: with an average SNP coverage between 0.01× and 3.4×

implicit_arguments.description: Technology and innovation transfer accompanied genetic admixture
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: We propose that the transfer of critical innovations between farmers and transitional foragers/herders

implicit_arguments.description: The selected SNP panel (1.24 million) is representative for population genetic inference
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: enriched for a panel of 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms

implicit_arguments.description: Modern West Eurasian genetic variation is appropriate reference for ancient populations
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations, onto which data from the ancient individuals were projected

implicit_arguments.description: Sample preservation and recovery is representative of past populations
Y-chromosome and mitochondrial lineages reflect broader population history
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: In line with the autosomal data, the Y-chromosomal and mitochondrial DNA lineages

implicit_arguments.description: Absence of evidence for pathogens indicates absence of widespread disease
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: we found no evidence for pathogens among the CA individuals

implicit_arguments.description: Statistical models with P > 0.05 represent biologically plausible scenarios
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: results shown here were run with the parameter 'allSNPs: NO'

research_designs.name: Archaeogenomic population history reconstruction
research_designs.description: Integration of genome-wide ancient DNA data with archaeological context to reconstruct population dynamics, admixture events, and cultural transitions across southeastern Europe during the Copper Age and Bronze Age
research_designs.verbatim_quote: we analysed genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from the contact zone between southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning this critical time period

research_designs.name: Multi-proxy ancestry modelling
research_designs.description: Combining multiple statistical approaches (PCA, f-statistics, qpAdm) to characterise and model genetic ancestry from multiple contributing populations
research_designs.verbatim_quote: To assess the genetic ancestry and variation of the newly typed individuals we first performed principal component analysis (PCA)... Distal qpAdm modelling... confirmed minimal amounts of EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry

research_designs.name: Temporal transect sampling
research_designs.description: Strategic sampling across multiple time periods (Neolithic, Copper Age, Eneolithic, Early Bronze Age) and geographic locations to track genetic change over time
research_designs.verbatim_quote: In total, we report genome-wide data for 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals from eight distinct sites (Fig. 1) ranging from around 5400 to 2400 bc: Neolithic (n = 1), CA (n = 95), Eneolithic (n = 18) and EBA (n = 21)

research_designs.name: Comparative site analysis
research_designs.description: Systematic comparison of genetic profiles between contemporaneous sites to assess regional genetic structure and connectivity
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We found no evidence for between-site links up to the fourth to fifth degree and only two pairs of individuals (PIE003-VAR010 and YUN005-VAR030) shared at least two blocks greater than 20 cM indicative of a fifth to seventh degree relationship

methods.name: Ancient DNA extraction and library preparation
methods.description: DNA extraction from petrous bones and teeth using modified protocols, followed by UDG-half treatment library preparation
methods.verbatim_quote: DNA was extracted from all samples following a modified protocol refs. 63,64. DNA double-stranded libraries were built using a partial uracil-DNA-glycosylase (UDG-half) treatment

methods.name: Targeted SNP capture
methods.description: In-solution capture targeting 1.24 million SNPs for genome-wide analysis
methods.verbatim_quote: All samples were enriched for a panel of 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms (1,240,000 SNP panel)

methods.name: Principal Component Analysis
methods.description: PCA projection of ancient individuals onto modern West Eurasian genetic variation
methods.verbatim_quote: To assess the genetic ancestry and variation of the newly typed individuals we first performed principal component analysis (PCA) constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations, onto which data from the ancient individuals were projected

methods.name: F-statistics analysis
methods.description: Calculation of f3 and f4 statistics to assess genetic affinities and test for admixture
methods.verbatim_quote: outgroup f3 statistics suggest local genetic homogeneity throughout the CA in this region

methods.name: qpAdm ancestry modelling
methods.description: Quantitative ancestry proportion estimation using distal and proximal models
methods.verbatim_quote: Distal qpAdm modelling (Fig. 3a and Supplementary Table G) confirmed minimal amounts of EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry

methods.name: DATES admixture timing
methods.description: Estimation of admixture timing using ancestry covariance decay
methods.verbatim_quote: Using DATES to determine the time of admixture between SEE N and Iron Gates HG as a local HG ancestry, we obtained an admixture estimate of 16.3 ± 13.4 generations

methods.name: Identity-by-descent analysis
methods.description: Detection of shared genomic segments to infer genetic relatedness
methods.verbatim_quote: To specifically test for links between the contemporaneous SEE CA sites and for more distant genetic relatedness we explored signals of IBD sharing between individuals

methods.name: Runs of homozygosity analysis
methods.description: Analysis of ROH to infer parental relatedness and effective population size
methods.verbatim_quote: analysis of the runs of homozygosity (ROH) per individual using hapROH indicates low levels of parental background relatedness

methods.name: Y-chromosome haplogroup assignment
methods.description: Determination of Y-chromosomal lineages using targeted capture and manual assignment
methods.verbatim_quote: Y-chromosome haplogroups for all male individuals were assigned using the manual assignment method of Y-haplogroup calling

methods.name: Mitochondrial haplogroup assignment
methods.description: Determination of mitochondrial lineages using consensus sequences
methods.verbatim_quote: HaploGrep2 (v.2.4.0; ref. 84) was used to assign each consensus sequence to a specific mitochondrial haplogroup

methods.name: Radiocarbon dating
methods.description: AMS radiocarbon dating of skeletal samples for chronological placement
methods.verbatim_quote: Radiocarbon dating was carried out using accelerated mass spectrometry at the Curt-Engelhorn-Zentrum Archäometrie gGmbH in Mannheim, Germany

methods.name: Ancient DNA authentication
methods.description: Verification of ancient DNA authenticity through damage pattern and contamination analysis
methods.verbatim_quote: All libraries, except PTK001, yielded damage patterns characteristic of ancient DNA

methods.name: Genetic relatedness estimation
methods.description: Detection of close genetic relatives using READ software
methods.verbatim_quote: When testing for genetic relatedness in each of the SEE CA sites using READ, we detected only three first-degree and two second-degree relationships

methods.name: Pathogen screening
methods.description: Metagenomic screening for pathogen DNA in ancient samples
methods.verbatim_quote: Shotgun sequencing data were screened for the presence of pathogen DNA with the screening pipeline HOPS

methods.name: Imputation
methods.description: Genotype imputation for low-coverage ancient samples using GLIMPSE
methods.verbatim_quote: Samples were imputed using GLIMPSE (v.1.0.1) with the default parameters

protocols.name: Petrous bone sampling
protocols.description: Minimally invasive sampling of petrous portion of temporal bone
protocols.verbatim_quote: Petrous bones were sampled with a minimal invasive method

protocols.name: Tooth sampling
protocols.description: Sampling of inner pulp chamber from teeth
protocols.verbatim_quote: for the sampling of the teeth, the crown was separated from the root and the inner pulp chamber was drilled out

protocols.name: DNA extraction protocol
protocols.description: Modified DNA extraction from ancient skeletal remains
protocols.verbatim_quote: DNA was extracted from all samples following a modified protocol refs. 63,64

protocols.name: UDG-half library preparation
protocols.description: Double-stranded library preparation with partial UDG treatment
protocols.verbatim_quote: DNA double-stranded libraries were built using a partial uracil-DNA-glycosylase (UDG-half) treatment

protocols.name: Single-stranded library preparation
protocols.description: Non-UDG single-stranded library preparation for low-yield samples
protocols.verbatim_quote: For samples that did not meet the threshold for further analysis, we attempted to increase the DNA yield by using an automated protocol for producing single-stranded, non-UDG libraries

protocols.name: 1240K SNP capture
protocols.description: Targeted in-solution capture for 1.24 million SNPs
protocols.verbatim_quote: Libraries above the threshold of 0.1% endogenous DNA were enriched for around 1.2 million SNPs in a targeted in-solution capture (1,240,000 SNP capture)

protocols.name: PCA projection protocol
protocols.description: Ancient sample projection onto modern reference using smartpca
protocols.verbatim_quote: Data on the HO panel (around 600,000 SNPs) were used for PCA using the program 'smartpca' v.16000 (EIGENSOFT). Principal components were computed for 1,253 present-day western Eurasians from 77 different populations (Supplementary Table B) on which ancient individuals were projected, using the options 'lsqproject: YES' and 'shrinkmode: YES'

protocols.name: Outgroup f3 statistics
protocols.description: Calculation of f3 statistics using qp3Pop
protocols.verbatim_quote: Outgroup f3 statistics were calculated using qp3Pop to obtain the genetic relatedness of a target population to a set of ancient Eurasian populations since the divergence from an African outgroup

protocols.name: F4 statistics calculation
protocols.description: F4 statistics calculation using qpDstat
protocols.verbatim_quote: The f4 and f3 statistics were calculated using qpDstat and the f4mode: YES function

protocols.name: qpAdm modelling protocol
protocols.description: Ancestry proportion estimation using qpAdm with defined outgroups
protocols.verbatim_quote: Ancestry modelling and ancestry proportion estimation on the 1,240,000 SNP dataset was performed using qpAdm in ADMIXTOOLS (v.5.1; ref. 4). The following groups were used as a basic set of outgroups for distal modelling: Mbuti.DG, Turkey_Epipaleolithic, Iran_GanjDareh_N, Russia_MA1_HG.SG, Russia_Kostenki14, Italy_North_Villabruna_HG

protocols.name: DATES analysis protocol
protocols.description: Admixture timing estimation using DATES software
protocols.verbatim_quote: The software DATES (v.753) was used to estimate the time of the admixture events of ancient populations under the assumption that gene flow occurred as a single event and that the generation time is 28 years. DATES measures the decay of ancestry covariance to infer the admixture time and estimates the variance of this admixture using a jackknife approach. The following parameters were used for every run: binsize 0.001; maxdis 1; qbin 10; lovalfit 0.45

protocols.name: Imputation for IBD analysis
protocols.description: GLIMPSE imputation preprocessing for IBD detection
protocols.verbatim_quote: Samples were imputed using GLIMPSE (v.1.0.1) with the default parameters... Samples with more than 0.5× coverage on the 1,240,000 positions (around 550,000 SNPs) after imputation were included in IBD analysis

protocols.name: ancIBD analysis protocol
protocols.description: IBD sharing analysis using ancIBD software
protocols.verbatim_quote: IBD sharing analysis was done using ancIBD (v.0.4) on individuals with more than 600,000 SNPs and genotype probabilities > 0.99 after imputation with GLIMPSE. We used HapBLOCK to perform the IBD sharing estimation

protocols.name: hapROH analysis protocol
protocols.description: ROH detection using hapROH software
protocols.verbatim_quote: The software package HapROH (v.0.64) was used to analyse ROH on pseudohaploid 1,240,000 SNP capture data. Only samples with more than 400,000 SNPs were included in the analysis

protocols.name: YMCA Y-chromosome capture
protocols.description: Targeted Y-chromosome capture assay
protocols.verbatim_quote: For selected male individuals we also performed an inhouse capture assay for the Y chromosome (YMCA) which targets around 10.445 kB on the non-combining region of the Y chromosome

protocols.name: Y-haplogroup assignment protocol
protocols.description: Manual Y-chromosome haplogroup calling method
protocols.verbatim_quote: Y-chromosome haplogroups for all male individuals were assigned using the manual assignment method of Y-haplogroup calling as described in ref. 70

protocols.name: Mitochondrial haplogroup assignment protocol
protocols.description: HaploGrep2 assignment of mitochondrial haplogroups
protocols.verbatim_quote: a consensus sequence for each individual was retrieved using Geneious v.2019.2.3 (ref. 83). HaploGrep2 (v.2.4.0; ref. 84) was used to assign each consensus sequence to a specific mitochondrial haplogroup

protocols.name: AMS radiocarbon dating protocol
protocols.description: Accelerator mass spectrometry radiocarbon dating with IntCal20 calibration
protocols.verbatim_quote: Radiocarbon dating was carried out using accelerated mass spectrometry at the Curt-Engelhorn-Zentrum Archäometrie gGmbH in Mannheim, Germany... All samples were calibrated on the basis of the IntCal20 database and using OxCal v.4.4.2

protocols.name: DNA damage assessment protocol
protocols.description: MapDamage analysis for ancient DNA authentication
protocols.verbatim_quote: To analyse characteristic DNA damage in the form of G to A and C to T substitutions, mapDamage v.2.0.9 (ref. 74) was used

protocols.name: Contamination estimation protocol
protocols.description: ContamMix and ANGSD contamination assessment
protocols.verbatim_quote: estimated contamination for both sexes on the mitochondrium using ContamMix (Supplementary Table A)... The nuclear contamination for males was estimated using ANGSD

protocols.name: READ relatedness estimation protocol
protocols.description: Genetic relatedness estimation using READ software
protocols.verbatim_quote: Genetic relatedness was estimated using READ, using default parameter settings. Background relatedness was estimated using the median value, across all sites per temporal group

protocols.name: HOPS pathogen screening protocol
protocols.description: Metagenomic pathogen detection using HOPS pipeline
protocols.verbatim_quote: Shotgun sequencing data were screened for the presence of pathogen DNA with the screening pipeline HOPS (v.0.2). First, adaptor-clipped reads were mapped to a custom-made RefSeq database using MALT v.0.4.0 (ref. 94) in BlastN mode

protocols.name: GLIMPSE imputation protocol
protocols.description: Genotype imputation using GLIMPSE with 1000G reference
protocols.verbatim_quote: Samples were imputed using GLIMPSE (v.1.0.1) with the default parameters. Briefly, bam files were trimmed 2 bp to remove ancient DNA damage. We then determined genotype likelihoods from trimmed bam files using bcftools with the 1,000G panel... We used GLIMPSE_impute on genomic chunks of 2,000,000 bp with the buffer size of 200,000 bp to perform imputation

protocols.name: Sequence data processing pipeline
protocols.description: EAGER pipeline for ancient DNA sequence processing
protocols.verbatim_quote: After demultiplexing, EAGER v.1.92.56 (ref. 71) was used to process raw ancient DNA sequence data. Raw reads were trimmed for Illumina adaptor sequences using AdapterRemoval v.2.3.0 (ref. 72). Subsequently, reads were mapped to the human reference genome hs37d5 using BWA v.0.7.12 (ref. 73) and duplicates were removed using DeDup v.0.12.1

protocols.name: Genotype calling protocol
protocols.description: Pseudohaploid genotyping using pileupCaller
protocols.verbatim_quote: The resulting filtered bam files were genotyped with pileupCaller v.1.4.0.2 (ref. 76) by randomly calling one allele per position considering the human genome as a pseudohaploid genome (–randomHaploid)

protocols.name: Sex determination protocol
protocols.description: Genetic sex estimation from chromosome coverage ratios
protocols.verbatim_quote: We estimated the genetic sex by calculating the coverage on the X, Y and the autosomal chromosomes, for which the X and Y coverage is normalized by the autosomal coverage and the relative length of each sex chromosome

protocols.name: Double-indexing protocol
protocols.description: Illumina library indexing with unique index pairs
protocols.verbatim_quote: All libraries were double-indexed with a unique pair of indices

protocols.name: Shotgun screening protocol
protocols.description: Initial library screening for endogenous DNA content
protocols.verbatim_quote: First, all indexed libraries were screened by means of shotgun sequencing of 5 million reads on an Illumina HiSeq4000 or NextSeq500 sequencing platform using a single end (1 × 75 base pair (bp) reads) kit, followed by an assessment of human DNA content and DNA damage profiles (initial quality criteria)

protocols.name: Mitochondrial capture protocol
protocols.description: Targeted mitochondrial DNA capture for haplogroup assignment
protocols.verbatim_quote: An additional mitochondrial capture was performed for individuals for which enough reads could not be obtained as by-catch of the 1,240,000 capture, resulting in an average coverage of 64×

funding.acknowledgement_text: This research was funded by the Max Planck Society, the European Research Council under the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement nos 771234-PALEoRIDER, W.H.; 834616-ARCHCAUCASUS, S.H.; and 678901-FoodTransforms, P.W.S.) and the ERA.Net RUS Plus initiative (S&T-277-BIOARCCAUCASUS, S.H.).

data_availability.statement_text: The DNA sequences reported in this paper have been deposited in the European Nucleotide Archive under the accession number PRJEB62503.

machine_actionability.rationale: Data deposited in standard repository (ENA) with accession number, allowing programmatic access
No custom code repository provided; analysis relies on published software packages with version numbers specified

roles: W.H., S.H., P.W.S. and J.K. designed the study
R.K., G.G.-R., C.S., M.A.S., G.U.N., A. Chohadzhiev, A.S., K.P., S.R., M.L., I.M., B.G., K. Boyadzhiev, Y.B., K. Beutler and I.B. provided materials and resources
S.P., A.B.R., G.G.-R., C.S., G.U.N. and A. Childebayeva analysed the data
W.H., I.M., S.H., P.W.S., Y.B. and K. Boyadzhiev assisted with data interpretation
S.P., S.H., P.W.S., I.M., A.B.R. and W.H. wrote the manuscript with contributions from all co-authors

conflicts_of_interest.declaration_text: The authors declare no competing interests.

ethics_approval.approval_reference: Permission to work on the archaeological samples was granted by the respective excavators, archaeologist and curators and museum directors of the sites, who are co-authoring the study.

permit_details: Permissions granted from Regional Museum of History - Veliko Tarnovo
Institute for Archaeology Vasile Pârvan - Bucharest
Institute for Geography of Goethe University - Frankfurt/Main
Varna Regional Museum of History - Varna
National Institute of Archaeology with Museum at Bulgarian Academy of Sciences - Sofia

references_completeness.notes: 94 references cited covering methods, archaeological context, and comparative genetic studies

fair_assessment.assessment_notes: Strong FAIR compliance: DOI assigned, data in ENA with accession, detailed methods section with software versions. Minor deduction for lack of custom code repository. High interoperability through standard formats and established databases.

known_limitations: Some radiocarbon dates may be affected by freshwater reservoir effect
PTK001 excluded due to high contamination (~18%)
Low coverage (0.01×-3.4×) may affect precision of some ancestry estimates
pass_history: Pass 1: Liberal extraction - 67 evidence items, 65 claims, 10 implicit arguments
Pass 3: RDMAP extraction - 4 research designs, 15 methods, 29 protocols
Pass 4: Implicit RDMAP - none additional needed
Pass 6: Infrastructure extraction - FAIR 35/40, ENA PRJEB62503
